title: How to Install a Chimney Liner

steps.title: Inspect the chimney.
steps.content: Inspect the chimney. Use a light source on a string (or an inspection camera if you have one)to look for bends, or restrictions that could interfere with pulling the liner through.

steps.title: Determine the correct diameter of the liner.
steps.content: Determine the correct diameter of the liner. If for a wood stove/insert, consult the owners manual for proper sizing. For an open fireplace, look for a chart or calculator online.

steps.title: Measure the length from the top of the chimney crown to the area where the bottom termination should stop.
steps.content: Measure the length from the top of the chimney crown to the area where the bottom termination should stop. To ensure you have enough liner, add an additional 12 inches (30.5 cm).

steps.title: Purchase a stainless steel flexible chimney liner from your local hardware supplier.
steps.content: Purchase a stainless steel flexible chimney liner from your local hardware supplier. The liner should come with a kit that contains all the pieces needed.

steps.title: Remove the liner from the packaging, and straighten it on a flat surface.
steps.content: Remove the liner from the packaging, and straighten it on a flat surface. Hook up the bottom connector to the bottom of the liner. Fasten a hose clamp to the connection with a wrench. Don't fasten it too tightly.

steps.title: Determine whether to use an insulation blanket or a pour-in insulation.
steps.content: Determine whether to use an insulation blanket or a pour-in insulation. If there is more than 2" clearance between the liner and chimney wall on all sides, the blanket liner is best.

steps.title: If using the blanket liner, measure the circumference of the bottom termination connector, and multiply the number by 3.14.
steps.content: If using the blanket liner, measure the circumference of the bottom termination connector, and multiply the number by 3.14. Add 1 inch (2.5 cm) to be sure you have enough. The overlap can be trimmed later if necessary.

steps.title: Cut the blanket insulation from your chimney liner installation kit to the calculated measurement.
steps.content: Cut the blanket insulation from your chimney liner installation kit to the calculated measurement.

steps.title: Lay the cut insulation flat on the ground with the foil-side down.
steps.content: Lay the cut insulation flat on the ground with the foil-side down. Center the liner on top, and wrap it with the installation. As you pull the chimney liner insulation closed, leave a minimum of 1 inch (2.5 cm) overlap so that you can secure it with tape.

steps.title: Glue the wrap to the liner with adhesive spray as you go.
steps.content: Glue the wrap to the liner with adhesive spray as you go. In 12 inch (30.5 cm) increments, seal the seam with foil tape. Repeat this process until you have completely covered the liner with insulation.

steps.title: Secure the seam with 1 long, unbroken piece of foil tape to complete the insulating layer.
steps.content: Secure the seam with 1 long, unbroken piece of foil tape to complete the insulating layer.

steps.title: Unroll the wire mesh from the installation kit, and cover the entire insulated liner, including the bottom connector.
steps.content: Unroll the wire mesh from the installation kit, and cover the entire insulated liner, including the bottom connector.

steps.title: Attach hose clamps to 1 end of the liner to hold the mesh in place.
steps.content: Attach hose clamps to 1 end of the liner to hold the mesh in place. From the other end, pull the mesh taut over the liner. Fasten the remaining host clamps on that end, and make sure to keep the wire meshing tight. Use your tin snips to remove any mesh that overhangs the liner.

steps.title: Check the instructions on the liner kit.
steps.content: Check the instructions on the liner kit. Specific instructions on how to pull the liner through the chimney may vary slightly from the guidance here. When in doubt, always follow the manufacturer's instructions. The most difficult point is typically the damper in the top of the fireplace.

steps.title: Attach the rope found in your installation kit to the pulling cone or directly to the bottom connector, whichever applies to your specific kit.
steps.content: Attach the rope found in your installation kit to the pulling cone or directly to the bottom connector, whichever applies to your specific kit.

steps.title: Climb to the roof, and position yourself near the chimney.
steps.content: Climb to the roof, and position yourself near the chimney. Have a second person feed you the liner from ground level, and return to the bottom of the chimney to assist you in the installation process.

steps.title: Throw the pulling rope down the chimney for the second person to guide down the liner.
steps.content: Throw the pulling rope down the chimney for the second person to guide down the liner.

steps.title: Position the bottom connector at the rooftop opening of the chimney, and make sure it is centered to prevent damage to either the chimney or liner.
steps.content: Position the bottom connector at the rooftop opening of the chimney, and make sure it is centered to prevent damage to either the chimney or liner. Slowly guide the liner downward. The second person should aid in this process by gently pulling the rope to help the liner's descent.

steps.title: Complete the installation when the bottom connector has reached the appropriate position for your chimney height.
steps.content: Complete the installation when the bottom connector has reached the appropriate position for your chimney height. If necessary, cut the top of the liner with your tin snips to equal 4 inches (10.2 cm) higher than the chimney crown.

steps.title: Instruct the second person to hold the bottom connector into place.
steps.content: Instruct the second person to hold the bottom connector into place. Seal the chimney crown with silicone caulking. Place the chimney's top plate over the installed liner, and press it firmly into the caulk to seal it.

steps.title: Secure the quick connect clamp tightly around the liner.
steps.content: Secure the quick connect clamp tightly around the liner. Use the pre-drilled holes on the top plate to screw the connection together with 4 tap con screws.

steps.title: Fit the cap onto the collar of the top plate, and use your monkey wrench to tighten the hose clamp band on to the top plate collar.
steps.content: Fit the cap onto the collar of the top plate, and use your monkey wrench to tighten the hose clamp band on to the top plate collar. Make sure the connection is secure to complete the top termination.

steps.title: Climb down from the roof, and return to the fireplace entrance or chimney bottom.
steps.content: Climb down from the roof, and return to the fireplace entrance or chimney bottom.

steps.title: Attach the appliance connector to the liner and the bottom termination point.
steps.content: Attach the appliance connector to the liner and the bottom termination point.

steps.title: Locate the tee snout on the liner bottom.
steps.content: Locate the tee snout on the liner bottom. Use your tin snips to cut a hole in the insulation and meshing where the tee snout will connect to the tee body.

steps.title: Fasten together the tee snout and tee body using the pre-attached metal, and wrap it around the backside of the tee body.
steps.content: Fasten together the tee snout and tee body using the pre-attached metal, and wrap it around the backside of the tee body. Cover the connection with the leftover liner insulation.

steps.title: Connect the tee snout to your heating appliance.
steps.content: Connect the tee snout to your heating appliance. Complete the connection by attaching it to the heating appliance.
